results.title: Peg: a life to remember
results.brief_description: Peg and Bryan have been trekking all over the world since 1987. Bryan recalls their travels and the great times spent with his wife, who now has Alzheimer’s disease. Created as part of ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ in association with Vic Health and the Alzheimer’s Association.

group.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage

results.title: A Letter for Marie
results.brief_description: South African born Marie has been diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease. Her husband, Tom, speaks of their 33-years together and of the good times still to come. Created as part of ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ in association with Vic Health and the Alzheimer’s Association.

group.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage

results.title: Simmo, the man I love
results.brief_description: John’s reputation as a great pilot earned him the respect of his colleagues, especially one admirer, Yolanta. But towards the end of his career, it felt like he was losing his touch, something was wrong. Created as part of ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ in association with Vic Health and the Alzheimer’s Association.

group.title: Memory's voice: capturing stories of courage

results.title: Memories for mum
results.brief_description: Since emigrating from Malta in the 60’s, Tess and her husband have faced many challenges living in Australia and raising their boys. As Tess is now suffering from Alzheimer’s disease, her husband and sons pay tribute to a truly great woman. Created as part of ‘Memory’s Voice: Capturing Stories of Courage’ in association with Vic Helath and the Alzheimer’s Association.

results.title: Rain check on Christmas
results.brief_description: A father and his daughter re-tell the events that happened two days before Christmas, when the father was struck down with a heart attack. Made as part of ‘The Heart of the Story’ in association with Vic Health and the Heart Foundation.

results.title: Another day, another dollar: three short films about the history of work
results.brief_description:
“Projected memories: work in old films”: In 1947, a projectionist took a collection of instructional 16mm films about work to the bush. This short film includes excerpts from that collection covering early footage (1900s-1930s) of families on the land; factory workers; steel workers; coal miners; working women; the rise of trade-unions and the 8-hour day; peace campaign of 1938; the invention of the teleprinter; the arrival of the corner grocer shop and much more.
“Never done: women, work and history”: Focuses on women in the workplace from the mid-1800s through to the 1970s including footage of the first women’s union (1882); industrialisation and factory work; the birth of the modern office worker (1890s); equal pay for equal work movement; WWI and WWII women in the workforce; trade-unionism and feminism.
“Close to slavery: black work in white history”: It was government policy for First Nations peoples in Australia to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work. Then came the mission stations, removal of children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when First Nations Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.

results.title: Dandenong
results.brief_description: A walk down memory lane in this black and white 1950s footage of the Dandenong Trades Exhibition which includes shots of white goods, furniture and TVs, Holden cars, streetscape images and a fashion parade. Also shows a blind woman working swiftly to create a bristle scrubbing brush. Athol Adams footage is courtesy of Jenny and Owen Peake.
results.description: A walk down memory lane in this black and white 1950s footage of the Dandenong Trades Exhibition which includes shots of white goods, furniture and TVs, Holden cars, streetscape images and a fashion parade. results.title: Bad Street Brawler for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, manual and blurb card in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In Bad Street Brawler, the player plays the character Duke Davis, a former punk rocker and the “world’s coolest” martial artist. Duke has to work his way through each level beating up the crooks that get in his way. Before the start of the next stage, quotes are introduced to entertain the player, such as “Never trouble trouble until trouble troubles you”. The player’s moves are limited to kicks and punches but new moves and attacks become available as the game progresses, along with new enemy types such as gorillas flinging bananas, menacing stakeboarders and circus strongmen. Bad Street Brawler is one of two games designed specifically for Mattel’s Power Glove.
